text: This is a download from BBC Learning English.
To find out more, visit our website.
6 Minute English from BBCLearningEnglish.com
Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I’m Neil.
speaker: Neil

text: And I'm Sam. Many people have favourites.
My favourite colour, my favourite flavour, my favourite word.
What's yours, Neil?
Hmm, my favourite colour is green,
speaker: nincompoop

text: My favourite flavour is sweet and sour.
And, well, I don't know if it's my favourite, but there is a word I really like saying out loud.
Ninkam poop. It means a silly person.
For me, it's the taste of coffee and the smell of lavender or freshly baked bread.
Our favourite tastes, smells and colours are controlled by our five senses
speaker: Neil

text: Sight, sound, smell, taste and touch.
For most of us, they don't mix. We see colours and taste flavours, but we can't taste sounds.
But that's not how everyone's brain works.
Imagine being able to taste every word that you hear.
In this programme, we'll meet two sisters from Glasgow in Scotland
who can do just that. And as usual, we'll learn some new vocabulary as well.
Julie McDowell and her younger sister, Jen McCready, have synesthesia,
a neurological condition where two or more senses mix together.
speaker: synaesthesia

text: When synestheats, as they are called, hear a word, their sense of taste also becomes activated.
Words produce specific tastes on their tongues.
For example, when Jen hears the name of her daughter, Sophia, she tastes pink marshmallows.
And the name Leo tastes like noodles.
Well, hear more from the unusual sisters later, but first I have a question for you, Neil.
We've just heard what happens when Jen McCready hears the names Sophia and Leo.
But what does she taste when she hears the name?
Neil. Is it A, eggs and bacon, B, spaghetti hoops, or C, a jam sandwich?
Well, I don't know what this says about me, Sam, but I'm going to guess that it's C, a jam sandwich.
speaker: Sam

text: Okay, don't worry, Neil. I'll reveal the answer later in the programme.
Synesthesia isn't only about people like Julie and Jen who taste words.
It can be a mixing of any of our senses, a synesthet may hear colours or see sounds.
In fact, there could be as many as 150 different types of synesthesia.
For the Scottish sisters having synesthesia is a gift, something Jen explained when she talked with
BBC World Service programme, the Food Chain.
speaker: Sam

text: It's enjoyable. It's never anything that causes the only thing I always say is it's quite hard
for you to try and eat healthily because if you hear a word that maybe tastes like tuna,
I'll be like, oh, I need to get a tuna baguette now.
You know it's almost like being pregnant and having a craving.
speaker: cravingvivid

text: Words can be so vivid that you just want to eat that. That's the only negative I would say about it.
For Jen, the only drawback to synesthesia is that it can be hard to eat healthily,
because hearing certain words produces a craving, a strong feeling of wanting a particular food.
That could be because, for Jen, the sound of the word is so vivid – clear
speaker: vivid

text: detailed and powerful in her mind.
There's still much doctors don't know about why some people experience sense mixing,
while most of us experience each sense in isolation.
But it's clear that for Julie and Jen, synesthesia makes the world a more interesting,
colorful place.
Someone who can explain why so little is known about synesthesia is Guy Letchzina,
consultant neurologist at King's College London, an author of the book The Man Who Tasted Words.
Here he is speaking to BBC World Services, The Food Chain.
speaker: Neil

text: One of the problems with synesthesia is for many years it's been dismissed and it's been viewed as
people with an overactive imagination, something not real.
But actually what research in recent years has taught us is that it does have an underlying
neurological and genetic basis.
Guy says that in the past synesthesia was often dismissed,
considered unimportant or uninteresting.
speaker: dismissed overactive imaginations

text: Synesthetes were labelled people with overactive imaginations,
a tendency to imagine things that are not true.
But research is showing that the cause of synesthesia could run in the family.
Julie and Jen's brothers don't have synesthesia, but Jen's daughter does.
And with an estimated 4% of the world population having some form of sense mixing,
a world of new and exciting possibilities is opening up to millions.
Exciting possibilities like tasting someone’s name…
speaker: Sam

text: Remember in my question I asked what synesthetes Jen McCready tastes when she hears the name Neil.
Okay well I guess that Neil tastes like a jam sandwich.
Was I right?
Well Neil no, you don't taste like a jam sandwich.
speaker: Sam

text: In fact when Jen hears the name Neil she tastes spaghetti hoops.
Oh well it could be worse, the name Robert makes Jen taste rotten eggs.
Sorry to any Robert's listening.
Okay let's recap the vocabulary we've learned in this program about synesthesia,
a neurological condition where two or more senses mix together.
A ninkam poop is an informal way of saying a silly person.
A craving for something is the strong desire to have it
speaker: nincompoop

text: A vivid sensation is clear, strong and detailed in your mind.
speaker: vivid

text: When something is dismissed it's considered unimportant or uninteresting.
And finally, an overactive imagination is the tendency to imagine things that are not true
speaker: overactive imagination

text: Once again our six minutes are up.
If you've enjoyed this look into the weird and wonderful world of synesthesia
we hope you'll join us again next time for more chat, interesting issues and useful
vocabulary here at Six Minute English. Bye for now.
Goodbye.
